citation.article-title: Mycobacterium porcinum sp. nov., a porcine pathogen.

p.s: Description of Mycobacterium porcinum sp. nov.
Mycobacterium porcinum (por'ci num. L. adj. porcinum pertaining to swine)
The characteristics of the type strain are as follows.
Acid-fast rods (1.5 to 6 μm long by 0.5 μm wide); colonies on egg media are smooth to rough and non-photochromogenic and colonies on modified Sauton agar medium (2) are rough and dry.
Growth occurs after 3 days on egg media and at 28, 37, and 42 but not 45°C.

Resistant to the following agents (on Ogawa egg medium or Löwenstein-Jensen medium): p-nitrobenzoic acid (0.5 mg/ml), 5% NaCl, thiophene-2-carboxylic acid hydrazide (1 μg/ml), rifampin (25 μg/ml), ethambutol (5 μg/ml), sodium p-aminosalicylate (2 mg/ml), sodium salicylate (0.5 mg/ml), and hydroxylamine hydrochloride (0.5 mg/ml).
Tolerant to 0.2% picric acid, 0.2% sodium nitrite, and 0.1% sodium salicylate on modified Sauton agar medium.
Degrades p-aminosalicylate to form black formazan, but does not degrade salicylate.
Tween 80 is not hydrolyzed after 14 days.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite after 24 h.

Arylsulfatase positive after 3 days; catalase positive (foam height more than 100 mm); β-galactosidase negative; acid phosphatase negative; β-esterase positive, but α-esterase negative or, if not negative, weakly positive.
Amidase pattern: acetamidase, urease, nicotinamidase, pyrazinamidase , allantoinase, and succinamidase positive; benzamidase, isonicotinamidase, salicylamidase, and malonamidase negative.

Pattern of utilization of nitrogen compounds as simultaneous nitrogen and carbon sources: glutamate, serine, glucosamine, acetamide, monoethanolamine, and trimethylenediamine are utilized; benzamide is not utilized.

Pattern of utilization of carbohydrates as sole sources of carbon in the presence of ammoniacal nitrogen: acetate, citrate, succinate, malate, pyruvate, benzoate, fumarate, ethanol, n-propanol, n-butanol, isobutanol, propylene glycol, 1,3-butylene glycol, 2,3-butylene glycol, glucose, fructose, mannose, trehalose, inositol, and mannitol are utilized; malonate, 1,4-butylene glycol, sucrose, galactose, arabinose, xylose, rhamnose, and sorbitol are not utilized.
Acetamide, benzamide, urea, nicotinamide, pyrazinamide, nitrate, and nitrite are utilized as sole nitrogen sources in the presence of glycerol carbon.

The nine other strains examined had identical characteristics, except that one produced cells longer than 7 μm and six produced smooth colonies on egg media (however, all 10 strains formed rough dry colonies on modified Sauton agar medium).
The source of all 10 strains was the lymph nodes of swine which showed tuberculosis-like lymphadenitis.
The type strain is E10241-1 (= ATCC 33776).
